abstract: Many people with or connected to the mental illness approve of updating the name, a new survey shows. But some experts are not convinced it’s the answer.

abstract: The expert in positive psychology has a few simple ideas for sustaining mental well-being as Covid-19 continues.
snippet: The expert in positive psychology has a few simple ideas for sustaining mental well-being as Covid-19 continues.
lead_paragraph: Laurie Santos, a psychology professor at Yale University and host of The Happiness Lab podcast, is a leading expert in positive psychology, a relatively young field. Since she began teaching “The Science of Well-Being” in 2018, it has become the most popular course in Yale’s history, with nearly a quarter of students enrolling. The class, now online for free, applies what Dr. Santos calls a “preventative medicine approach” to mental health — harnessing science and evidence to help people lead more fulfilling lives.

headline.main: Laurie Santos Says Self-Care Doesn’t Have to Be Selfish
headline.print_headline: Self-Care Doesn’t Have to Be Selfish

headline.main: What We Dream When We Dream About Covid-19

abstract: “It makes you depressed, anxious that it’s never going to go away.”

Right away she knew she had likely been infected with Covid-19. As a nurse practitioner, Ms. Aston, 50, was confident she knew how to handle her symptoms, and disappeared to her bedroom to quarantine and rest.

headline.main: For Long-Haulers, Covid-19 Takes a Toll on Mind as Well as Body

lead_paragraph: The morning walk before a holiday meal can feel like an act of advance penance: a show of restraint before the feast, best performed under a pale sun, amid a lonely scatter of leaves and with a determination to keep the campfire in sight. March off too slowly — or too far — and you’ll only annoy your companions, who likewise skipped breakfast to save room for the banquet.

headline.main: Don’t Get Mad, but ‘Hangry’ Isn’t Really Angry

Coming next spring is “Becoming Wild,” on the culture of animals, and a young adult version of “Beyond Words,” on the capabilities of dogs and wolves.

abstract: Humility is not the boldest of personality traits, but it’s an important one, studies find. And it’s hard to fake.
snippet: Humility is not the boldest of personality traits, but it’s an important one, studies find. And it’s hard to fake.
lead_paragraph: In their day jobs, research psychologists don’t typically need safety goggles, much less pith helmets or Indiana Jones bullwhips. There’s no rappelling into caves to uncover buried scrolls, no prowling the ocean floor in spherical subs, no tuning of immense, underground magnets in the hunt for ghostly subatomic particles.

headline.main: Be Humble, and Proudly, Psychologists Say
headline.print_headline: Humility Is Something to Boast About

abstract: They’re far from us on the tree of life, and their brains are very different, and some scientists say we should take care before we assume that cephalopods sleep like we do.
snippet: They’re far from us on the tree of life, and their brains are very different, and some scientists say we should take care before we assume that cephalopods sleep like we do.
lead_paragraph: Heidi the octopus is sleeping. Her body is still, eight arms tucked neatly away. But her skin is restless. She turns from ghostly white to yellow, flashes deep red, then goes mottled green and bumpy like plant life. Her muscles clench and relax, sending a tendril of arm loose.

headline.main: Was Heidi the Octopus Really Dreaming?
headline.print_headline: Sleeping Octopus: Eight Arms, 40 Winks  And Who Knows How Many Dreams?

abstract: The research center, with $17 million from donors, aims to give “psychedelic medicine” a long-sought foothold in the scientific establishment.
snippet: The research center, with $17 million from donors, aims to give “psychedelic medicine” a long-sought foothold in the scientific establishment.
lead_paragraph: Since childhood, Rachael Petersen had lived with an unexplainable sense of grief that no drug or talk therapy could entirely ease. So in 2017 she volunteered for a small clinical trial at Johns Hopkins University that was testing psilocybin, the active ingredient in magic mushrooms, for chronic depression.

headline.main: Johns Hopkins Opens New Center for Psychedelic Research
headline.print_headline: Center to Explore Psychedelics for Mental Health

abstract: “Something happened to the brain” of diplomats who reported odd ailments, a brain-imaging study suggests. But the cause is still unclear.
snippet: “Something happened to the brain” of diplomats who reported odd ailments, a brain-imaging study suggests. But the cause is still unclear.
lead_paragraph: In late 2016, dozens of United States diplomats working in Cuba and China began reporting odd mental symptoms: persistent headaches, vertigo, blurred vision, hearing phantom sounds. Since then, scientists and commentators have groped for plausible explanations. Deliberate physical attacks, involving microwaves or other such technology? Or were psychological factors, subconscious yet mind-altering, the more likely cause?

headline.main: Were U.S. Diplomats Attacked in Cuba? Brain Study Deepens Mystery
headline.print_headline: Study Reports Trauma In Brains of Diplomats

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

abstract: Researchers have found a way to detect “covert consciousness” that could aid the recovery of people with severe brain injuries.
snippet: Researchers have found a way to detect “covert consciousness” that could aid the recovery of people with severe brain injuries.
lead_paragraph: Doctors have known for years that some patients who become unresponsive after a severe brain injury nonetheless retain a “covert consciousness,” a degree of cognitive function that is important to recovery but is not detectable by standard bedside exams. As a result, a profound uncertainty often haunts the wrenching decisions that families must make when an unresponsive loved one needs life support, an uncertainty that also amplifies national debates over how to determine when a patient in this condition can be declared beyond help.

headline.main: ‘It’s Gigantic’: A New Way to Gauge the Chances for Unresponsive Patients
headline.print_headline: ‘It’s Gigantic’: A New Way to Gauge the Chances for Unresponsive Patients

lead_paragraph: You know that face your dog makes, the one that’s a little bit quizzical, maybe a bit sad, a bit anticipatory, with the eyebrows slanted? Sometimes you think it says, “Don’t be sad. I can help.” Other times it quite clearly asks, “No salami for me?”

headline.main: Those Puppy Dog Eyes You Can’t Resist? Thank Evolution

abstract: A pilot study offers “a very promising start” in the effort to help people recover from traumatic brain injuries.
snippet: A pilot study offers “a very promising start” in the effort to help people recover from traumatic brain injuries.
lead_paragraph: More than 3 million Americans live with disabling brain injuries. The vast majority of these individuals are lost to the medical system soon after their initial treatment, to be cared for by family or to fend for themselves, managing fatigue, attention and concentration problems with little hope of improvement.

headline.main: Doctors Use Electrical Implant to Aid Brain-Damaged Woman

abstract: Psychologists have studied personal space and physical contact for decades. Here's why people get so uncomfortable.

abstract: Some things aren’t worth remembering. Science is slowly working out how we might let that stuff go.
snippet: Some things aren’t worth remembering. Science is slowly working out how we might let that stuff go.
lead_paragraph: Whatever its other properties, memory is a reliable troublemaker, especially when navigating its stockpile of embarrassments and moral stumbles. Ten minutes into an important job interview and here come screenshots from a past disaster: the spilled latte, the painful attempt at humor. Two dates into a warming relationship and up come flashbacks of an earlier, abusive partner.

headline.main: Can We Get Better at Forgetting?
headline.print_headline: The Joy of Letting Things Go

abstract: Planning on quitting the social platform? A major new study offers a glimpse of what unplugging might do for your life. (Spoiler: It’s not so bad.)
snippet: Planning on quitting the social platform? A major new study offers a glimpse of what unplugging might do for your life. (Spoiler: It’s not so bad.)

abstract: The Harvard psychologist says he is no starry-eyed optimist. It’s just that the data don’t lie.
snippet: The Harvard psychologist says he is no starry-eyed optimist. It’s just that the data don’t lie.
lead_paragraph: Steven Pinker, a cognitive psychologist at Harvard, has been known to take provocative positions. He has argued that women are intrinsically different from men, that we are more driven by our genes than academics like to acknowledge, and that society is getting less violent over time — despite the mass shootings and other atrocities we hear about daily.

headline.main: Steven Pinker Thinks the Future Is Looking Bright
headline.print_headline: Steven Pinker Thinks The Future Is Bright

abstract: Biology was supposed to cure what ails psychiatry. Decades later, millions of people with mental disorders are still waiting.
snippet: Biology was supposed to cure what ails psychiatry. Decades later, millions of people with mental disorders are still waiting.
lead_paragraph: Nothing humbles history’s great thinkers more quickly than reading their declarations on the causes of madness. Over the centuries, mental illness has been attributed to everything from a “badness of spirit” (Aristotle) and a “humoral imbalance” (Galen) to autoerotic fixation (Freud) and the weakness of the hierarchical state of the ego (Jung).

headline.main: When Will We Solve Mental Illness?
headline.kicker: 11 things we’d really like to know

abstract: Stigma often prevents patients from acknowledging an Alzheimer’s diagnosis. A series of high-profile disclosures may help change that.

abstract: Most research on depression focuses on the afflicted, a new paper argues, overlooking a potentially informative group: people who have recovered.
snippet: Most research on depression focuses on the afflicted, a new paper argues, overlooking a potentially informative group: people who have recovered.
lead_paragraph: A generation ago, depression was viewed as an unwanted guest: a gloomy presence that might appear in the wake of a loss or a grave disappointment and was slow to find the door. The people it haunted could acknowledge the poor company — I’ve been a little depressed since my father died — without worrying that they had become chronically ill.

headline.main: What’s Life Like After Depression? Surprisingly, Little Is Known

abstract: Animals, like humans, are reluctant to give up on pursuits they’ve invested in, psychologists report.
snippet: Animals, like humans, are reluctant to give up on pursuits they’ve invested in, psychologists report.
lead_paragraph: Suppose that, seeking a fun evening out, you pay $175 for a ticket to a new Broadway musical. Seated in the balcony, you quickly realize that the acting is bad, the sets are ugly and no one, you suspect, will go home humming the melodies.

headline.main: Mice Don’t Know When to Let It Go, Either

abstract: The World Health Organization has made “internet gaming” a diagnosable disorder. But many experts aren’t even sure it exists.
snippet: The World Health Organization has made “internet gaming” a diagnosable disorder. But many experts aren’t even sure it exists.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization last month added “internet gaming disorder” to its manual of psychiatric diagnoses, and the reaction was, shall we say, muted.

headline.main: Endless Gaming May Be a Bad Habit. That Doesn’t Make It a Mental Illness.

abstract: Experts say the parents and children split apart at the border could face difficult reunions. Holding them indefinitely could be even worse.
snippet: Experts say the parents and children split apart at the border could face difficult reunions. Holding them indefinitely could be even worse.
lead_paragraph: The chaotic process of reuniting thousands of migrant children and parents separated by the Trump administration’s “zero tolerance” policy poses great psychological risks, both short- and long-term, mental health experts said on Friday. So does holding those families indefinitely while they await legal proceedings, which could happen under the president’s new executive order.

headline.main: Reuniting and Detaining Migrant Families Pose New Mental Health Risks
headline.print_headline: The Cost to Mental Health Of Indefinite Detainment

abstract: The longer children remain in institutional settings, the greater their risk of depression, post-traumatic stress and other mental health problems.
snippet: The longer children remain in institutional settings, the greater their risk of depression, post-traumatic stress and other mental health problems.
lead_paragraph: Some youngsters retreat entirely, their eyes empty, bodies limp, their isolation a wall of defiance. Others cannot sit still: watchful, hyperactive, ever uncertain.

headline.main: A Troubling Prognosis for Migrant Children in Detention: ‘The Earlier They’re Out, the Better’
headline.print_headline: A Dicey Psychological Outlook for Migrant Children in Detention

lead_paragraph: A political activist. A high-powered attorney. A feminist author.

snippet: The question of whether the benefit from viewing a da Vinci is different from enjoying a visit to Pornhub or McDonald’s is dividing psychologists and neuroscientists.
lead_paragraph: A battle over pleasure has broken out. On Twitter and in the pages of scientific journals, psychologists, neurologists and neuroscientists are forging alliances over the question of whether pleasure we get from art is somehow different from the pleasure we get from candy, sex or drugs.

headline.main: Why Scientists Are Battling Over Pleasure
headline.print_headline: Mona Lisa and Pornhub as Equals?

lead_paragraph: The California case in which 13 siblings were found imprisoned at home earlier this week is shocking, but not without precedent. Lurid cases have come to light over the years of children locked in closets and basements, held captive by parents who have crumbled under the weight of drugs, extreme religious conviction, personality disorders or their own abusive backgrounds.

headline.main: Treatment Offers Hope for Imprisoned California Siblings

abstract: Tempted to grab that once-in-a-lifetime eclipse snapshot? Feel free: Taking pictures helps people engage with and remember experiences more deeply, according to new research.
snippet: Tempted to grab that once-in-a-lifetime eclipse snapshot? Feel free: Taking pictures helps people engage with and remember experiences more deeply, according to new research.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, I will be one of millions watching the moon punch a hole in the sun during the Great American Eclipse of 2017. In preparation, I’ve been thinking about how I want to spend my roughly two minutes of totality, when day surrenders, briefly, to coronal night. Should I try to capture my experience with photos? Or should I soak in the moment as deeply as I can?

headline.main: Taking Photos Won’t Take You Out of the Moment, Study Suggests
headline.print_headline: Photographic Memories: Savor the Moment. Take a Picture.

abstract: Human behavior researchers offer four reasons why it's worth experiencing totality in a large group, even if the toilets overflow.
snippet: Human behavior researchers offer four reasons why it's worth experiencing totality in a large group, even if the toilets overflow.
lead_paragraph: Right about now, maybe you’re looking at your bank account and reports of unprecedented traffic and wondering why you thought it was a good idea to experience the eclipse in the particular spot you chose.

abstract: There are active steps you can take during and after a crisis to speed your emotional recovery.

abstract: For the last 20 years, academic researchers have gathered at this event to share and debate their studies without being mocked.
snippet: For the last 20 years, academic researchers have gathered at this event to share and debate their studies without being mocked.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The shuttle driver got lost on the way to the 10th Procrastination Research Conference, threatening to derail the schedule. Still by 9:20 a.m. last Thursday, the 60 or so attendees had already completed check-in at DePaul University, welcome remarks and the first of dozens of presentations.

headline.main: What We Finally Got Around to Learning at the Procrastination Research Conference
headline.print_headline: This Conference Didn’t Get Put Off

abstract: After devising a scale for treating attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, Dr. Conners later expressed dismay over how loosely the label was being applied.
snippet: After devising a scale for treating attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, Dr. Conners later expressed dismay over how loosely the label was being applied.
lead_paragraph: Keith Conners, whose work with hyperactive children established the first standards for diagnosing and treating what is now known as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D. — and who late in life expressed misgivings about how loosely applied that label had become — died on July 5 in Durham, N.C. He was 84.

headline.main: Keith Conners, Psychologist Who Set Standard for Diagnosing A.D.H.D., Dies at 84
headline.print_headline: Keith Conners, 84; Aided A.D.H.D. Diagnoses

abstract: New federal rules may make it easier for researchers to conduct behavioral experiments. Critics worry that academics cannot judge whether their studies are harmful.
snippet: New federal rules may make it easier for researchers to conduct behavioral experiments. Critics worry that academics cannot judge whether their studies are harmful.
lead_paragraph: If you took Psychology 101 in college, you probably had to enroll in an experiment to fulfill a course requirement or to get extra credit. Students are the usual subjects in social science research — made to play games, fill out questionnaires, look at pictures and otherwise provide data points for their professors’ investigations into human behavior, cognition and perception.

headline.main: Some Social Scientists Are Tired of Asking for Permission
headline.print_headline: Less Scrutiny for Social Scientists

abstract: Seven decades after she began, Dr. Milner continues to explore the biology of memory and how the brain’s many parts function together.

lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — The driving instructor wiped his brow with a handkerchief, and not just because of the heat. His student — a grown woman, squinting over the dashboard — was ramming the curb in an effort to parallel park.

headline.main: Brenda Milner, Eminent Brain Scientist, Is ‘Still Nosy’ at 98

abstract: In a new book, the social psychologist Adam Alter warns that our devotion to digital devices has morphed into something very much like addiction.
snippet: In a new book, the social psychologist Adam Alter warns that our devotion to digital devices has morphed into something very much like addiction.
lead_paragraph: In a new book, “Irresistible: The Rise of Addictive Technology and the Business of Keeping Us Hooked,” the social psychologist Adam Alter warns that many of us — youngsters, teenagers, adults — are addicted to modern digital products. Not figuratively, but literally addicted.

headline.main: Why We Can’t Look Away From Our Screens

abstract: Some therapists were thrilled that the the wife of the vice president supports their field. Others worry that her husband’s politics hurt the very people they treat.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, D.C. — For much of her childhood, RyAnn Watson has been hospitalized for excruciating flare-ups of sickle cell disease. Now 16, she takes refuge from her pain in an art studio at MedStar Georgetown University Hospital. On a recent Friday, she was sketching the sandstone towers of the Smithsonian castle with a burnt-red coloring pen, under the watch of her therapist, Tracy Councill.

headline.main: Karen Pence Picks a Cause, and Art Therapists Feel Angst
headline.print_headline: Political Support Divides Art Therapists

abstract: Researchers found that big hip swings and asymmetric arm and thigh movements give the impression of being a better dancer.
snippet: Researchers found that big hip swings and asymmetric arm and thigh movements give the impression of being a better dancer.
lead_paragraph: If you’re reading this at home, pause and put on a song you can’t resist dancing to. Go on, bop your head to the beat. Let yourself wiggle a bit. Throw in some arms and legs. If you’re reading this at work, maybe imagine these things at your desk.

headline.main: What Makes a Woman a Good Dancer? Watch the Hips, a Study Says
headline.print_headline: Dance Lessons: At the Club, Arms May Flail but Hips Tell the Tale

abstract: A sincere apology can be powerful medicine with surprising value for the giver as well as the recipient.

lead_paragraph: Most people say “I’m sorry” many times a day for a host of trivial affronts – accidentally bumping into someone or failing to hold open a door. These apologies are easy and usually readily accepted, often with a response like, “No problem.”

headline.main: The Right Way to Say ‘I’m Sorry’
headline.print_headline: The Right Way to Say ‘I’m Sorry’

abstract: Even a gentle walk can lift your mood and improve life satisfaction.
snippet: Even a gentle walk can lift your mood and improve life satisfaction.
lead_paragraph: When people get up and move, even a little, they tend to be happier than when they are still, according to an interesting new study that used cellphone data to track activities and moods. In general, the researchers found, people who move are more content than people who sit.

headline.main: Get Up and Move. It May Make You Happier.
headline.print_headline: Getting Up Can Cheer You Up

abstract: An evolutionary riddle suggests plants should give bats a sugar-heavy jolt, but a new study points to why the bats drink watery nectars in higher volumes.
snippet: An evolutionary riddle suggests plants should give bats a sugar-heavy jolt, but a new study points to why the bats drink watery nectars in higher volumes.
lead_paragraph: This is how we’re taught to count as children: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. Yet our innate grasp of quantities isn’t linear. We’re more likely to experience the world in ratios, like 1, 2, 4, 8, 16. It’s easier for us to see the difference between one and two marbles than 15 and 16 of them.

headline.main: Bats Like Their Plant Nectar Sweet — Though Maybe the Plants Know Better
headline.print_headline: Sugar Rush: Bats Want More Nectar, Not Better Nectar

snippet: A new analysis of Google Books and The New York Times archives suggests that when things get bad, the words do, too.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of the election, it’s clear American society is fractured. Negative emotions are running amok, and countless words of anger and frustration have been spilled. If you were to analyze this news outlet for the ratio of positive emotional words to negative ones, would you find a dip linked to the events of the past few weeks?

headline.main: With Shifts in National Mood Come Shifts in Words We Use, Study Suggests
headline.print_headline: Language Lesson: How National Mood Can Affect Our Words

abstract: Each person’s threshold for experiences that provoke fear, like Halloween haunted houses, is made up of a unique recipe that blends nature and nurture.
snippet: Each person’s threshold for experiences that provoke fear, like Halloween haunted houses, is made up of a unique recipe that blends nature and nurture.
lead_paragraph: Halloween is here again. That means your co-workers have planted surprise spiders around the office. You’ve been invited to a haunted hayride. Your neighbor’s yard has a full cemetery, rigged with motion detectors and pop-up zombies. Chicken-livered from the start, I have always dreaded this time of year. Haunted houses, ghost tours and horror film fests are not my thing, and why people love having the daylights scared out of them completely escapes me.

headline.main: A Scaredy-Cat’s Investigation Into Why People Enjoy Fear

abstract: Research into the metaphors used to describe inventions found that they carried implicit associations about men and women’s stereotypical gender roles.
snippet: Research into the metaphors used to describe inventions found that they carried implicit associations about men and women’s stereotypical gender roles.
lead_paragraph: Try searching for “top inventors of all time” on Google. Start counting the images along the top of your search page, and you’ll go through 29 photos of men before you reach Hedy Lamarr, an Austrian actress from Hollywood’s golden age. In 1942, she shared a patent for a technology to prevent enemies from detecting messages in radio signals. This “Secret Communication System” eventually led to today’s mobile phone technology and to secure military communications.

headline.main: Metaphorically Speaking, Men Are Expected to be Struck by Genius, Women to Nurture It
headline.print_headline: Big Ideas: Inspiration by Gender

snippet: After watching a scenario between an actor and a man in a King Kong suit, apes appeared to know what the actor believed.

lead_paragraph: Almost four million American teenagers have just started their freshman year of high school. Can they learn better ways to deal with all that stress and insecurity?

abstract: Even those who seem fine often experience significant declines in specific aspects of physical and emotional health.
snippet: Even those who seem fine often experience significant declines in specific aspects of physical and emotional health.
lead_paragraph: Losing a beloved life partner is never easy at any age, no matter the circumstance. The loss can be sudden and totally unexpected — a fatal heart attack, traffic accident or natural tragedy like a flood or earthquake. Or the loss can be long in coming from a progressive illness that gives the surviving spouse weeks, months, even years to prepare for and presumably ”adjust” to its eventual inevitability.

headline.main: When a Spouse Dies, Resilience Can Be Uneven
headline.print_headline: Recovery Varies After a Spouse Dies

abstract: About 8.4 percent of Americans interviewed in a study had depression, but of those, only 28.7 percent had received any treatment.
snippet: About 8.4 percent of Americans interviewed in a study had depression, but of those, only 28.7 percent had received any treatment.
lead_paragraph: Using data from a survey that screened more than 46,000 Americans for depression, researchers found evidence that the condition is not properly diagnosed in many people. And even when diagnosed correctly, depression often goes untreated.

headline.main: Depression Is Poorly Diagnosed and Often Goes Untreated
headline.print_headline: Mind; Depression Is Often Untreated

abstract: To differing degrees, we’ve all been guilty of cryptomnesia, the process of claiming an original thought already encountered elsewhere.
snippet: To differing degrees, we’ve all been guilty of cryptomnesia, the process of claiming an original thought already encountered elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Sleigh Bells, an indie rock band, has filed a copyright infringement suit against Demi Lovato, accusing the pop star of stealing, at the very least, the beat of one of its songs.

abstract: Mothers who co-slept with their babies past 6 months of age reported less satisfaction in their marriages and in how well they and their partners were working together as parents, a study found.
snippet: Mothers who co-slept with their babies past 6 months of age reported less satisfaction in their marriages and in how well they and their partners were working together as parents, a study found.
lead_paragraph: As new parents, Penn State researcher Doug Teti and his wife were co-sleepers, sharing their bed at night with all three of their children, now grown.

headline.main: When Kids Are in the Bed: The Ups and Downs of Co-Sleeping
